original: “bhante nāgasena, yo na paṭisandahati, nanu so yoniso manasikārena na paṭisandahatī”ti?
analyzed: bhante nāgasena yaḥ na paṭisandahati nanu saḥ yonisaḥ manasikārena na paṭisandahati iti
translated: “But, revered Nāgasena, is it not by proper reflection that he does not re-arise?”

original: “Yoniso ca, mahārāja, manasikārena paññāya ca aññehi ca kusalehi dhammehī”ti.
analyzed: yoniso ca mahā rāja manasikārena paññāya ca aññehi ca kusalehi dhammehi iti
translated: “By proper reflection, Great King, and by wisdom and by other good things as well.”

analyzed: nanu bhante yonisas manasikāro yā iva paññā ati
translated: “But, revered sir, is not proper reflection itself wisdom?”

original: “Na hi, mahārāja, añño manasikāro, aññā paññā, imesaṁ kho, mahārāja, ajeḷakagoṇamahiṁsaoṭṭhagadrabhānampi manasikāro atthi, paññā pana tesaṁ natthī”ti.
analyzed: na hi mahā rāja aññaḥ manasikāraḥ aññā paññā imesam kho mahā rāja ajeḷaka goṇa mahisa oṭṭha gadrabhānam pi manasikāraḥ atthi paññā pana tesam natthi iti
translated: “No, indeed, Great King. Proper reflection is one thing, wisdom is another. Even goats, sheep, buffaloes, cattle and deer, Great King, have proper reflection, but they have no wisdom.”
“You are a wise man, revered Nāgasena.”
The seventh question on proper reflection is finished.
